subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Quikscript extensions to Shavian (or separate script)
msgSnippet: Paul Tremblay became a member of the Read Alphabet group in late September, 2007.  At that time, he had recently moved to Louisville, Kentucky near where I
messageBody:
Paul Tremblay became a member of the Read Alphabet group in late September, 2007.  At that time, he had recently moved to Louisville, Kentucky near where I live.  We never met in person.  He was very enthusiastic about QS and designed the Thoth font soon after becoming a member.  I provided a modest amount of assistance in reviewing his initial font design and making some suggestions to him.

Paul set up the daily news in QS, which took AP news releases and transliterated them into QS.  It was useful in providing timely QS readings for reading practice.  When he was unable to continue doing that, the news disappeared.  It would be nice to see it come back as lack of reading material is one of the major stumbling blocks which keep people from increasing their reading speed.

In December, 2007, he was working on a QS dictionary and a number of posts were sent between Paul and Benct Philip Jonsson who was also working on a dictionary proposal at that time.

He asked for someone to take over the news on 1/14/08 because he did not have the time to continue it.  His last post was only 2 days later.  Since then we have not heard from him.  He is not currently a member of the group as far as I am aware.

There is no particular reason to view the letter names he used as canonical.

Regards,


Paige



On 4/22/2013 10:23 AM, John Cowan wrote:
 

Michael Everson scripsit:

> Who is Tremblay and why should we care?

Paul H. Tremblay is a member (or former member) of this group, and
that's all I know about him. The Tremblay chart, however, is widely
disseminated: it's available in the files section of this group and at
Wikimedia Commons, and is used in the Wikipedia article on QS. Its names
have been frequently used (including by me) in discussions on this list.
They are in my opinion superior to Read's: he seems to have gone to some
lengths to make his names sound as similar as possible, a considerable
regression from the excellent Shavian letter names (which remind me of
John Wells's lexical set names).

> The Unicode guys still find the Runic names annoying.

Tant pis.

--
The Imperials are decadent, 300 pound John Cowan <cowan@...>
free-range chickens (except they have http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
teeth, arms instead of wings, and
dinosaurlike tails). --Elyse Grasso
